body_html: @w4nderlust I see it the opposite way -- the current solution is a more general one. It allows class weighting as a simple case, but also allows weighting the instances individually (this is sometimes needed if you either are given weights beforehand, or if you for example want the same sum of positive/negative examples to be the same, for example).

body: @w4nderlust I see it the opposite way -- the current solution is a more general one. It allows class weighting as a simple case, but also allows weighting the instances individually (this is sometimes needed if you either are given weights beforehand, or if you for example want the same sum of positive/negative examples to be the same, for example).
